title: AB 2340
content: The people of California enact the following. Section 626.9 of the Penal Code, known as the Gun-Free School Zone Act of 1995, prohibits possessing a firearm in a school zone without written permission. Exceptions include possession in a residence, business, or private property not part of school grounds. When transporting an unloaded pistol, revolver, or concealed firearm in a locked container or trunk of a vehicle, it is allowed under the law. This does not apply to other firearms not capable of being concealed on the person. When in grave danger due to a restraining order or exempt from carrying a concealed firearm, it is permissible to possess a firearm. The belief of being in grave danger must be reasonable. When holding a valid license to carry a firearm, it is unlawful to discharge a firearm within 1,000 feet of a school, except in certain circumstances. The definition of a concealed firearm is the same as specified in Sections 25400 and 25610. In a school zone, possessing a firearm is prohibited and punishable by imprisonment for two, three, or five years. The definitions of "concealed firearm," "firearm," and "locked container" are specified in relevant sections of the law. Possessing a firearm within 1,000 feet of a school is prohibited and punishable by imprisonment for two, three, or five years under certain circumstances, such as previous felony convictions or being prohibited from possessing a firearm. Possessing a firearm within 1,000 feet of a school is prohibited and punishable by imprisonment for two, three, or five years under certain circumstances. If the firearm is a concealed pistol, revolver, or other concealable firearm, the offense is punished as a felony with imprisonment for one year in a county jail or two, three, or five years in state prison. Violating this law results in imprisonment for three, five, or seven years. Every person convicted under this section for a misdemeanor violation of possessing a firearm near a school, with a previous misdemeanor offense, shall be imprisoned in a county jail for at least three months. For felony violations with a previous misdemeanor offense, imprisonment in a county jail for at least three months is required if probation is granted or sentence is suspended. Every person convicted under this section for a felony violation of possessing a firearm near a school with a previous felony offense must be imprisoned in a county jail for a minimum of three months if probation is granted or sentence is suspended. The court must apply a three-month minimum sentence, unless probation or a suspended sentence is deemed more appropriate for the interests of justice. In such cases, the court must specify the reasons for deviating from the minimum imprisonment requirement. Possessing a loaded firearm on university campus grounds without permission from the university president or designated authority is punishable by imprisonment for two to four years. The university must post notices at entrances on noncontiguous property stating that firearms are prohibited. Possessing a firearm on university campus grounds without written permission from the university president or designated authority is punishable by imprisonment for one, two, or three years. The university must post notices at entrances on noncontiguous property stating that firearms are prohibited. For the purposes of this section, a firearm is considered loaded when there is a cartridge or shell in or attached to the firearm. This section does not require posting notice about the prohibited conduct. This section exempts certain individuals from the regulations, including peace officers, military personnel, and armored vehicle guards. This section exempts security guards, shooting ranges at schools, retired peace officers, and appointed peace officers from the regulations. Section 30310 of the Penal Code prohibits carrying ammunition onto school grounds without written permission, except for sworn law enforcement officers. The section does not apply to individuals with a valid concealed firearm license and a domestic violence protective order. (2) A peace officer from another state or federal government on official duties in California, (3) any person assisting in making an arrest or preserving peace when summoned by an officer, (4) a member of the military performing duties, (5) an armored vehicle guard on duty, (6) a peace officer listed in specific sections, (7) any duly appointed peace officer, and (8) an honorably retired peace officer are exempt from carrying ammunition onto school grounds under Penal Code Section 30310. (8) An honorably retired peace officer listed in subdivision (c) of Section 830.5 and any other honorably retired peace officer authorized to carry a firearm are exempt from carrying ammunition onto school grounds. (9) A person carrying ammunition in a locked container or trunk of a vehicle on school grounds is also exempt. (10) A person with a valid concealed firearm license protected by a domestic violence protective order is exempt as well. Violation of this section may result in up to six months in jail, a fine of up to $1,000, or both.
